Nevada plant personnel are trained and equipped to respond to accidental chemical releases. The program can be summarized as follows:
-Plant personnel and emergency responders receive emergency response training.
-Emergency response plans are periodically reviewed and updated.
-The plant conducts periodic emergency drills, including critiques.
-Plant human resources communicates with the Story County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).
-If a release with the potential for off-site impact occurs:
-The plant emergency alarm is sounded.
-The plant Incident Command System is activated.
-Plant emergency personnel respond.
-Community responders are notified and asked to respond as appropriate.
Programs detailing emergency responder training and emergency equipment maintenance can be found in the Nevada site VEAP (Verbio North America Emergency Action Plan), the site computer, and hard copy based training records. All these activities are monitored to ensure they remain current.

Five-year Accident History
There have been no RMP reportable accidents on this facility to date.

Planned Changes To Improve Safety
Making our processes safer is an on-going program at the Nevada site. Employee suggestions, capital improvements, audit programs, and various other activities help to ensure that we provide safe, reliable processes. Other programs aimed at improving process safety and our emergency response planning include:
- Recommendations developed during cyclic process hazards analyses that reduce the risks associated with our processes.
- Providing additional process safety training to technical personnel in topics such as chemical reactivity, layer of protection analysis, and safety instrumented systems risk analysis.
- Expanding periodic process safety metrics reporting to management.

Emergency Response Program
The site emergency response program is documented in the VEAP (Verbio North America Emergency Action Plan) and is available for review by all employees. 
Verbio’s crisis management structure clearly defines roles and responsibilities for managing response to incidents. The structure and process are designed to allow incidents to be managed at the appropriate level of the organization. At the facility level, immediate actions to protect life and safety are first responded to by the ICT, which has defined key roles and follows a principal of management by objective. The ICT is led by the Verbio Incident Commander (IC).
The Verbio ICT in turn reports executive leadership and must keep senior management apprised of the situation. The EMT is responsible for the overall response of Verbio and is the conduit to the additional resources of the corporation. The Crisis Management Team (CMT) will provide direction and overall control of Verbio response through the strategy and policy decisions it makes.

Facility Description
The Verbio Nevada Biorefinery site consists of approximately 65 acres located approximately two miles west of Nevada, IA. The Verbio Nevada, LLC (Verbio) Biorefinery in Nevada, Iowa has been modified in two phases from the Nevada Cellulosic Ethanol Facility originally located at the plant site. Phase 1 (or the “straw plant”) uses crop-residue to produce biomethane and humus. Phase 1 includes straw pretreatment, fermentation, biogas cleaning, solids separation, digestate treatment, and ancillary support operations. Phase 2 (or the “corn plant”) is a dry mill corn ethanol plant. Phase 2 includes corn receiving and handling, a fermentation process, distillation, and evaporation processes (producing 200-proof ethanol, syrup, and corn oil), two biogas cleaning lines to produce biomethane, and ancillary support operations. The site uses the following EPA regulated RMP chemicals at levels above their process threshold quantities:
Toxics – None              Flammables – Methane, Isopentane, Pentane

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The Nevada site manufacturing areas follow the requirements set out in the VEAP (Verbio North America Emergency Action Plan) and OSHA Process Safety Management. This standard includes and embraces the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.120 and 40 CFR Part 68. 

The standard involves the following activities as listed below:
- A documented process technology system covers hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.
- Extensive active and passive preventative and mitigating systems are strategically located.
- Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.
- Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity.
- Quality Assurance ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications and proper assembly.
- Maintenance personnel are trained and experienced.
- Contractors are trained and qualified.
